questions.question: During graded force production, the typical order of motor unit recruitment described in the notes is:
options: larger, fast motor units first; smaller, slow units later
smaller, slower motor units first; then progressively larger, more powerful units
random recruitment that depends mainly on visual feedback
simultaneous recruitment of all motor units once a movement begins
questions.answer: smaller, slower motor units first; then progressively larger, more powerful units

questions.question: In the Stroop task description, which statements are consistent with the mechanisms highlighted in the notes?
options: Interference is greatest when the written word and ink colour match
The task depends primarily on occipital cortex processing with minimal prefrontal involvement
The task is explained as a pure test of motor output without attentional selection demands
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In the basal ganglia indirect pathway description, inhibiting the external globus pallidus (GPe) has which key downstream consequence?
options: It increases inhibition of the subthalamic nucleus (STN), suppressing its output
It reduces inhibition of the STN, allowing the STN to drive GPi/SNr activity
It directly excites thalamic neurons projecting to motor cortex
It blocks dopamine release from substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) into the striatum
questions.answer: It reduces inhibition of the STN, allowing the STN to drive GPi/SNr activity

questions.question: Which event is described as critical for NMDA-receptor mediated LTP induction in hippocampal synapses?
options: Chloride influx through GABA receptors in the postsynaptic neuron
Sodium efflux that hyperpolarises the postsynaptic membrane
Calcium influx through NMDA receptors after sufficient depolarisation removes the magnesium block
A presynaptic decrease in glutamate release probability
questions.answer: Calcium influx through NMDA receptors after sufficient depolarisation removes the magnesium block

questions.question: In the rTMS intervention study on hemispatial neglect described, which outcome was reported?
options: Improvements were reported only after a single stimulation session
Improvements were absent in the multiple-session stimulation group
both A and B
Significant improvements were observed in the group receiving repeated stimulation sessions (ten applications)
questions.answer: Significant improvements were observed in the group receiving repeated stimulation sessions (ten applications)

questions.question: Dysdiadochokinesia (in the context of cerebellar dysfunction) refers to:
options: difficulty recognising objects despite intact primary vision
tremor that occurs only at rest and disappears during movement
impaired ability to perform rapid alternating movements
a profound loss of motivation and slowed goal-directed behaviour
questions.answer: impaired ability to perform rapid alternating movements

questions.question: According to the ATOM account in the dyscalculia notes, time, space and number are proposed to share a common neural underpinning in:
options: the right intraparietal sulcus
the hippocampus
the ventral occipito-temporal stream
the amygdala
questions.answer: the right intraparietal sulcus

questions.question: In the emotion regulation paradigm described for depression, which pattern most directly captured the reward-related abnormality reported?
options: Greater sustained nucleus accumbens activation to positive images specifically during amplification trials
No group differences in nucleus accumbens activity across any instruction conditions
Depressed participants failed to sustain nucleus accumbens activation when amplifying positive emotion
Selective hyperactivation of occipital cortex to negative images regardless of instruction
questions.answer: Depressed participants failed to sustain nucleus accumbens activation when amplifying positive emotion

questions.question: Regarding cortical hyperarousal during sleep in PTSD (as summarised), which statements are consistent with the notes?
options: Hyperarousal is indexed as increased power in higher frequency EEG bands during sleep
Hyperarousal during sleep was described as interacting with daytime hyperarousal domains
Hyperarousal was linked to disturbed sleep continuity (eg more awakenings / difficulty falling asleep)
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: Sleep spindles were described as being generated in the thalamic reticular nucleus (TRN), which is composed predominantly of:
options: dopaminergic projection neurons
GABAergic inhibitory neurons
cholinergic motor neurons
glutamatergic pyramidal neurons
questions.answer: GABAergic inhibitory neurons

questions.question: Which observation best captures the classic demonstration that non-declarative learning can be preserved despite profound amnesia (as described in the notes)?
options: Normal delayed recall of a complex figure after a 15-minute distractor period
Normal acquisition of new episodic memories for post-surgery daily events
Improved performance across repeated mirror-drawing trials despite no recollection of having practised
Above-chance recognition of recently studied paired associates after distraction
questions.answer: Improved performance across repeated mirror-drawing trials despite no recollection of having practised

questions.question: Which pattern of impairment best matches the notes' summary of what defines the core deficit in dense hippocampal amnesia across many tasks?
options: Performance collapses only when material is nonverbal; verbal learning is intact
Impairment is most evident when information must be retrieved after a delay in which the person is not actively rehearsing it
Immediate repetition and short-term maintenance are profoundly impaired even without distraction
all of the above
questions.answer: Impairment is most evident when information must be retrieved after a delay in which the person is not actively rehearsing it

questions.question: Which region is described as the primary gateway between the hippocampus and the broader neocortex?
options: perirhinal cortex
parahippocampal cortex
entorhinal cortex
anterior cingulate cortex
questions.answer: entorhinal cortex

questions.question: In the anterior–posterior distinction described for hippocampal connectivity, the anterior hippocampus is characterised as receiving relatively greater input from:
options: parahippocampal cortex (spatial layout coding)
amygdala and perirhinal cortex (emotional/item-related inputs)
primary motor cortex and cerebellum (motor timing inputs)
occipital cortex (early visual inputs)
questions.answer: amygdala and perirhinal cortex (emotional/item-related inputs)

questions.question: Which of the following was explicitly listed as one of the four inhibition functions associated with DLPFC control?
options: initiating tetanic muscle contractions at the neuromuscular junction
removing irrelevant information from working memory
generating place-cell firing fields in CA1
increasing reward sensitivity via nucleus accumbens activation
questions.answer: removing irrelevant information from working memory

questions.question: Within prospect theory (as described), which component captures the idea that people do not treat objective probabilities linearly (eg overestimating rare outcomes)?
options: diminishing marginal utility
expected value maximisation
probability weighting
normative rationality
questions.answer: probability weighting

questions.question: Which statements match the notes' description of motor programs?
options: They centrally organise and control many degrees of freedom in an action
They can be used without ongoing feedback from the moving limb
They show equivalence (actions can be produced independently of specific muscle groups)
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: When discussing learned motor skills becoming less reliant on external monitoring, which pattern was described as evidence for supplementary motor area (SMA) involvement?
options: SMA activity decreases as sequences become well learned, indicating it is mainly a novice-learning region
SMA activity increases as a task becomes learned and can be performed without strong reliance on visual cues
both A and B
SMA activity is selectively driven only by nociceptive interoceptive afferents
questions.answer: SMA activity increases as a task becomes learned and can be performed without strong reliance on visual cues

questions.question: According to the anatomical description of the insula, interoceptive inputs first enter the insular cortex primarily via:
options: anterior insula
posterior insula
ventrolateral prefrontal cortex
angular gyrus
questions.answer: posterior insula

questions.question: In schizophrenia sleep physiology, which observation was used to argue for a broader thalamic dysfunction beyond spindle count alone?
options: Thalamus–cortex hyperconnectivity correlated with fewer sleep spindles
Hippocampus–amygdala hypoconnectivity correlated with increased slow-wave sleep
both A and B
Thalamus–cortex hyperconnectivity correlated with fewer sleep spindles
questions.answer: Thalamus–cortex hyperconnectivity correlated with fewer sleep spindles

questions.question: Which symptom triad was described as necessary for a diagnosis of Balint's syndrome?
options: Simultanagnosia, optic ataxia, oculomotor apraxia
Simultanagnosia, prosopagnosia, optic ataxia
Hemispatial neglect, simultanagnosia, oculomotor apraxia
Acalculia, agraphia, finger agnosia
questions.answer: Simultanagnosia, optic ataxia, oculomotor apraxia

questions.question: In the systems consolidation account described, hippocampal damage is predicted to show what temporal profile in memory loss?
options: Older memories are more vulnerable than recent memories because the cortex is fragile
Recently acquired memories are especially vulnerable, whereas older memories are relatively preserved as information is transferred out of hippocampus
No temporal gradient is expected if the hippocampus is damaged
Only semantic memory should be affected, not episodic memory
questions.answer: Recently acquired memories are especially vulnerable, whereas older memories are relatively preserved as information is transferred out of hippocampus

questions.question: In the interference-resolution paradigm described (negative recency), increased ventrolateral PFC activity was associated with which probe type?
options: A probe that was present in the current set (positive trial)
A probe absent from the current set but present in a recent previous set (negative recency)
A probe that had never been presented at any point (novel foil)
A probe that had been repeatedly practised during retrieval training
questions.answer: A probe absent from the current set but present in a recent previous set (negative recency)

questions.question: Which findings were described as evidence that slow-wave sleep plays an active role in stabilising declarative memories?
options: Enhancing slow-wave rhythm via stimulation improved paired-associate learning
During slow-wave sleep, reactivation/replay of prior learning was described as strengthening memory traces
Odour cue re-presentation during sleep improved later memory relative to wake, while wake cueing could worsen memory
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In the retrieval-and-control lecture summary, which region was highlighted as being recruited during both episodic and semantic retrieval when task-relevant information is weak and competition must be controlled?
options: posterior cingulate cortex
hippocampus
angular gyrus
ventrolateral prefrontal cortex (left inferior frontal gyrus)
questions.answer: ventrolateral prefrontal cortex (left inferior frontal gyrus)

questions.question: According to the basal ganglia account in Parkinson's disease, which imbalance best matches the notes' description?
options: excess direct pathway output with insufficient indirect pathway output
insufficient direct pathway output with insufficient indirect pathway output
excess indirect pathway output with excess direct pathway output
insufficient direct pathway output with excess indirect pathway output (hypokinesia)
questions.answer: insufficient direct pathway output with excess indirect pathway output (hypokinesia)

questions.question: In Garfinkel's interoception framework, interoceptive awareness is best captured by which combination?
options: objective interoceptive accuracy alone
subjective self-report of bodily feelings irrespective of objective accuracy
both A and B
heartbeat-evoked potentials without any metacognitive judgement
questions.answer: both A and B

questions.question: In Avery et al.'s mapping work described, which pattern of insula activation best matches the summary in the notes?
options: Interoceptive attention preferentially activated anterior insula, while taste attention activated posterior insula
Interoception and taste activated entirely non-overlapping insula territories with no shared regions
Interoceptive attention showed greater posterior insula activity, while exteroceptive taste attention showed greater anterior insula activity (with some overlap in mid/posterior regions)
Only mid-insula differentiated the tasks; anterior and posterior insula did not
questions.answer: Interoceptive attention showed greater posterior insula activity, while exteroceptive taste attention showed greater anterior insula activity (with some overlap in mid/posterior regions)

questions.question: Which outcome was reported in the smoking–insula lesion example used to illustrate the insula's role in conscious urges?
options: Smokers with insula lesions became more relapse-prone due to loss of autonomic regulation
Smokers with insula damage were reported as over 100 times more likely to quit smoking without relapse than smokers with lesions elsewhere
Smokers with insula damage showed improved sleep spindles and memory consolidation but unchanged smoking behaviour
Smokers with insula lesions lost procedural learning but retained craving
questions.answer: Smokers with insula damage were reported as over 100 times more likely to quit smoking without relapse than smokers with lesions elsewhere

questions.question: In the monoamine treatment discussion, why were antidepressant effects described as typically taking weeks to emerge?
options: because dopamine itself must first cross the blood–brain barrier
because treatments must overcome homeostatic feedback mechanisms (often requiring ~2–4 weeks)
because hippocampal place cells must reorganise during REM sleep before symptoms change
because antipsychotic D2 blockade must first reduce hallucinations
questions.answer: because treatments must overcome homeostatic feedback mechanisms (often requiring ~2–4 weeks)

questions.question: In the fear conditioning/extinction work described, which pair of findings characterised PTSD patients at extinction recall (24 hours later) relative to trauma-exposed controls?
options: enhanced extinction retention with increased vmPFC activity
normal extinction learning but reduced fear acquisition
both A and B
enhanced amygdala activity only during extinction learning, with no recall differences
questions.answer: both A and B

questions.question: Which sequence best matches the reaching-related visuomotor pathway described in the advanced movement lecture?
options: parieto-occipital extrastriate area (PO) → mediodorsal parietal (MDP) → medial intraparietal (MIP) → dorsal premotor area (PMd)
dorsal extrastriate cortex (ES) → anterior intraparietal sulcus (AIP) → ventral premotor area (PMv)
primary visual cortex → amygdala → ventromedial PFC → primary motor cortex
thalamus → cerebellum → spinal cord → supplementary motor area
questions.answer: parieto-occipital extrastriate area (PO) → mediodorsal parietal (MDP) → medial intraparietal (MIP) → dorsal premotor area (PMd)

questions.question: In the CA1 NMDA receptor knock-out mouse work described, which behavioural profile was reported?
options: Impaired spatial learning alongside preservation of other forms of learning such as classical conditioning
Enhanced spatial learning due to reduced interference between similar environments
Selective impairment in classical conditioning with intact spatial learning
No measurable learning impairment across tasks
questions.answer: Impaired spatial learning alongside preservation of other forms of learning such as classical conditioning

questions.question: Which cueing pattern best distinguishes semantic aphasia from semantic dementia in the notes' comparison?
options: Semantic dementia shows large improvements with phonological cues, whereas semantic aphasia shows little cue benefit
Both disorders show no cueing benefit because semantic knowledge is equally degraded
Semantic aphasia shows much larger improvement with phonological cues than semantic dementia
all of the above
questions.answer: Semantic aphasia shows much larger improvement with phonological cues than semantic dementia

questions.question: In the retrieval-network summary, default mode network (DMN) engagement was reinterpreted as being driven primarily by:
options: effortful controlled retrieval when target information is weak
strong/easy retrieval that can come relatively automatically (often from strong cues)
exclusive involvement in episodic memory with no role in semantic retrieval
motor preparation demands during memory tasks
questions.answer: strong/easy retrieval that can come relatively automatically (often from strong cues)

questions.question: Which statement best captures the double dissociation described between amnesia and semantic dementia?
options: Both conditions primarily show procedural learning deficits with preserved declarative memory
Semantic dementia reflects hippocampal damage, whereas amnesia reflects anterior temporal lobe degeneration
Amnesia typically shows episodic impairment with relative preservation of semantic memory, whereas semantic dementia shows semantic impairment with relative preservation of episodic memory
Both conditions show identical impairments because episodic and semantic memory are a single system
questions.answer: Amnesia typically shows episodic impairment with relative preservation of semantic memory, whereas semantic dementia shows semantic impairment with relative preservation of episodic memory

questions.question: In the heartbeat-evoked potential (HEP) study described for general anxiety disorder, what was the pattern reported in healthy controls across eyes-open vs eyes-closed resting states?
options: HEP magnitude decreased in eyes-closed relative to eyes-open
HEP magnitude was greater in eyes-closed than eyes-open
HEP magnitude was identical across both conditions
HEP was not measurable in healthy participants and only appeared in anxiety
questions.answer: HEP magnitude was greater in eyes-closed than eyes-open

questions.question: In the attentional blink paradigm with cardiac timing described, which stimulus category showed selective facilitation at systole (heart contraction)?
options: fear faces
neutral faces
houses
all face types equally
questions.answer: fear faces

questions.question: In the cardiac-cycle manipulation work on racial stereotyping described, systole presentation was reported to:
options: exacerbate stereotyped responses (eg weapon/tool judgements and shooting decisions became more biased in the threat-relevant direction)
eliminate bias by increasing executive control over responses
reduce stereotype-consistent responding by weakening salience signals
affect only subjective confidence, with no change in behaviour
questions.answer: exacerbate stereotyped responses (eg weapon/tool judgements and shooting decisions became more biased in the threat-relevant direction)

questions.question: In Bliss and Lomo's hippocampal LTP demonstration, which observation most directly reflects synapse specificity?
options: High-frequency stimulation increased responses equally for both stimulated and unstimulated pathways
Conditioning reduced responses in the stimulated pathway due to habituation
both A and B
Conditioning increased response to stimulation of the conditioned pathway, while the unconditioned pathway's response remained unchanged
questions.answer: Conditioning increased response to stimulation of the conditioned pathway, while the unconditioned pathway's response remained unchanged

questions.question: Which set of approaches were described as ways to link hippocampal mechanisms (including NMDA-dependent processes) to spatial memory performance?
options: Hippocampal lesions in animals to test task dependence on hippocampus
Pharmacological disruption using an NMDA receptor antagonist during spatial learning
Transgenic knock-out mice lacking NMDA receptors in CA1 to test causal contribution
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: According to the dopamine hypothesis summary in the schizophrenia lecture notes, which mapping is correct?
options: Hyperdopaminergic mesocortical pathway → positive symptoms; hypodopaminergic mesolimbic pathway → negative symptoms
Dopamine is uniformly increased throughout the brain, producing both positive and negative symptoms equally
Hyperdopaminergic mesolimbic pathway → positive symptoms; hypodopaminergic mesocortical pathway → negative symptoms
Dopamine is irrelevant; serotonin alone explains both positive and negative symptoms
questions.answer: Hyperdopaminergic mesolimbic pathway → positive symptoms; hypodopaminergic mesocortical pathway → negative symptoms

questions.question: In the mechanistic description of NMDA receptors during LTP, what allows calcium to pass through NMDA channels?
options: GABA binding opens NMDA channels directly
Sufficient depolarisation expels magnesium from the NMDA channel pore
Chloride influx through NMDA channels unmasks calcium permeability
Dopamine binding to NMDA receptors removes the magnesium block
questions.answer: Sufficient depolarisation expels magnesium from the NMDA channel pore

questions.question: In the think/no-think paradigm described, successful suppression was associated with which neural pattern?
options: increased activation in prefrontal cortex alongside decreased activation in hippocampus
decreased activation in prefrontal cortex alongside increased activation in hippocampus
increased activation in occipital cortex only, with no hippocampal modulation
amygdala-driven activation increases were necessary and sufficient for suppression success
questions.answer: increased activation in prefrontal cortex alongside decreased activation in hippocampus

questions.question: Sleep spindles were described as arising from which core thalamic mechanism?
options: Sustained excitation of thalamocortical neurons without inhibitory input
Powerful inhibition by TRN neurons followed by rebound burst firing at spindle frequency
A dopaminergic burst from VTA that entrains thalamic oscillations
Cerebellar re-entrant circuits that synchronise cortical networks during NREM sleep
questions.answer: Powerful inhibition by TRN neurons followed by rebound burst firing at spindle frequency

questions.question: Which set of findings were used to support interoceptive abnormalities/differences in anorexia nervosa in the notes?
options: Meta-analytic evidence of lower interoceptive sensibility on eating-disorder interoception scales
Reduced pleasantness ratings of affective touch relative to controls (controlling for anhedonia)
Altered insula engagement during gastric interoception (eg reduced dorsal mid-insula activity during stomach-focused trials)
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In the numerical distance effect imaging described for dyscalculia, which pattern distinguished controls from children with dyscalculia?
options: Children with dyscalculia showed greater right intraparietal sulcus activation as distance increased, while controls did not
Controls showed a numerical-distance-related activation in right intraparietal sulcus that was not observed in dyscalculia
Both groups showed identical intraparietal activation but differed only in occipital cortex responses
Neither group showed any right parietal involvement during numerical comparison
questions.answer: Controls showed a numerical-distance-related activation in right intraparietal sulcus that was not observed in dyscalculia

questions.question: In the direct pathway description of basal ganglia function, what is the immediate functional consequence of striatal GABAergic output onto GPi/SNr?
options: It reduces GPi/SNr inhibitory output to the thalamus, effectively opening a gate for movement-related thalamocortical drive
It increases inhibition of thalamic neurons, suppressing movement initiation
It directly contracts skeletal muscle via acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction
It prevents cortical motor programmes from being selected by increasing indirect pathway activity
questions.answer: It reduces GPi/SNr inhibitory output to the thalamus, effectively opening a gate for movement-related thalamocortical drive

questions.question: In the heat-pain predictive coding study summary (Geuter et al.), which region's activity patterns were described as aligning with predictive coding of pain rather than raw intensity coding?
options: posterior insula
primary motor cortex
anterior insula
all of the above
questions.answer: anterior insula

questions.question: In the Eriksen Flanker Task description, strong involvement was attributed to which region, likely due to conflict detection demands?
options: anterior cingulate cortex (ACC)
amygdala
hippocampus
cerebellum
questions.answer: anterior cingulate cortex (ACC)
